text: Oh, good evening chair and committee members. So take the report as read and I'll just highlight a few things along the way. So of particular note is the flood hazard mapping. So if you recall, we sent out just under a thousand letters to properties were identified as like possible to flood in a one in 100 year event. And we've then done more surveying since then, and we're down to probably it'll be confirmation of less than a hundred houses  we'll actually flood in a 1 in 100 year event, and so they'll be the houses that have letters and notices on their limbs forming of that. We haven't sent those letters out yet due to COVID, etc. We've still got a few surveys to finish and we'll save those letters till we're back working normally.  We've currently got four reticulation staff who have had their training in backflow testing, and four more were due to go this month, but that's been cancelled for obvious reasons. We're continuing to work with the DIA and Water New Zealand on the transition programme for the proposed water reform, and all that work's been undertaken on a no regrets basis.  So we're working as what would transition look like, but no decisions have been made. So it's just a no regrets working basis. And last financial year, compliance was met for all the water treatment plants for both bacteria and protozoa. And we had not one zone non-compliance in the Pucrimi scheme, where the maximum level between sample days was exceeded. So we have to take samples on a schedule, supposed to be every three days.  Um, and, uh, scheduling was out by one day for one, one sample. So we were non-compliant for the year, which is fair enough. We deserve that. Um, and for this report in period starting, um, this financial year with two water treatment plants and non-compliant for bacteria, uh, with all plants compliant for protozoa. And I'll talk about that in a while. And the proof pickle removes zone again is non-compliant for July.  due to two positive E. coli samples within reticulation. We're still investigating that, but the evidence suggests that safe water was provided and it's likely to have been a cross-contamination event in the sample, as opposed to anything bad in the water schemes. And I'll flick onto our summer campaign. So for our summer campaign, you remember we have the four alert levels, one to four,  um, for water conservation, typically for the last 10 years, they've been based on a, on a. Capacity driven level. So when capacity reaches 70% of what we can achieve, we move through the alert levels until we finally get to alert level four. Um, obviously we've spent an awful lot of money over the last few years to improve our capacity. So we need to look at a different way of approaching this summer's campaign. So we're looking at it being, being more a educational.  campaign around water conservation rather than outright. When we've reached this trigger level, we'll go to it. So we'll still have alert water alert levels, but that hope there'll be more more educational basis than than than a formal campaign. We're still working on what that looks like. So hopefully we'll have that ready by one December.  And next is on section 5.4 where we had those non-compliances at the treatment plants. So again, when water leaves the treatment plants, it's required to, we had chlorine and that's required to have a contact time before it leaves the treatment plant of 30 minutes after it's been dosed. And on two different plants, we failed to show, to prove evidence that we'd complied with that 30 minutes.  in our first report to the district health board. So we're not currently non-compliant. We are looking at retrieving data from other sources other than the stuff we send directly online to confirm we did have that 30 minute contact time. So hopefully those non-compliances will be removed in due course. The parallel road water treatment plan, which is almost finished. It's currently being commissioned.  and we're currently sending water over to TMU2 from there. And we're just waiting for final sign off on that water being compliant, and then we can put it in service, which will be good. And the Cambridge Wastewater Treatment Plant, we're still working through the consent, and we're also starting, there's a list there of enabling works we'll be starting shortly.  to enable when construction does happen in a couple of years' time for that to happen smoothly. So there's a list of items there that we'll be working through. And then on stormwater hotspots, if you recall a while ago, we talked about rain gardens, which we're looking at installing on Lake Tukutu. We're almost ready to let a contract for that work to be undertaken. And we'll be putting in about 12 rain gardens around the roundabout by the White Church in Cambridge.  and down to the Queen Street roundabout. And again, we'll be looking at having a very strong educational program along with that to educate the community why we're doing rain gardens, how they work and what they're doing to protect the lake.
